column1: The infection may be due to bacteria or viruses.
- Submandibular glands: These 2 glands are located just under both sides of the lower jaw and carry saliva up to the floor of the mouth under the tongue.
Salivary gland infections are somewhat common, and they can return in some people.
Viral infections such as mumps often affect the salivary glands.
Mumps is a rare problem today because of the MMR vaccine.

Bacterial infections are most often the result of a: - Blockage from salivary duct stones - Poor cleanliness in the mouth (oral hygiene) - Low amounts of water in the body, most often while in the hospital - Smoking - Chronic illness

Symptoms include: - Abnormal tastes, foul tastes - Decreased ability to open the mouth - Dry mouth - Fever - Mouth or facial "squeezing" pain, especially when eating - Redness over the side of the face or the upper neck - Swelling of the face (particularly in front of the ears, below the jaw, or on the floor of the mouth)
